titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Office of Finance, Vice President, Office Files of Roger G. Kennedy
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Office of Finance, Vice President, Office Files of Roger G. Kennedy FA581
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Nancy Ng Tam and Brian Bleich, The Winthrop Group

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-02-17 10:06:56 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Office of Finance, Vice President, Office Files of Roger G. Kennedy
did.abstract: Roger G. Kennedy joined the Ford Foundation in 1970 as Vice President of the Office of Finance. Charged with steering the Foundation towards achieving long-term sustainability despite the high inflation of the 1970s, he restructured the expenditures, investment strategies, and portfolio. He also served as a key advisor on financial matters to President McGeorge Bundy and to the Board of Trustees Finance Committee, and frequently prepared dockets and presented reports and recommendations to the Committee. The Finance Committee, initiated by the Board of Trustees in 1953, set investment policy and monitored the performance of the Foundation's portfolio. The Office Files of Roger G. Kennedy span from 1969 to 1979 and consist of memoranda, reports, articles, speeches, background and meeting materials documenting his work as Vice President of the Office of Finance (1969-1977) and later as Vice President of the Office of the Arts (1978-1979). The bulk of the collection consists of Finance Committee dockets. These dockets contain agenda books (later called "Treasurer's Reports") with portfolio reviews and summaries of investment holdings. Also part of Mr. Kennedy's Committee records are memoranda and correspondence pertaining to the Foundation's efforts to divest and diversify its portfolio of Ford Motor Company stock. Other files contain research memoranda and recommendations by investment research staff within the Office of Finance.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Appendix A: Reports â€“ Unpublished reports written by Ford Foundation staff and consultants were removed from their original folders, scanned and transferred to the Archives' collection of staff and consultant reports. See Appendix A for a list of these reports and their specific assigned number. The reports are listed in alphabetical order by author. The assigned number may be used to access reports in the online catalog.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: This collection consists of files removed by Mr. Kennedy when he left the Foundation and then returned in April 2011. Mr. Kennedy donated other papers to the Smithsonian Institution, where he had served as Director of its National Museum of American History from 1979 to 1992.
The records created by the Office of the Treasurer's staff originally were not part of Mr. Kennedy's files. The decision to incorporate them into the collection was made during processing.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II. Office of the Arts Files, 1977-1979

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Office Files of Roger G. Kennedy span from 1969 to 1979 and consist of memoranda, reports, articles, speeches, background and meeting materials documenting his work as Vice President of the Office of Finance (1969-1977) and the Office of the Arts (1978-1979).

The bulk of the collection consists of Finance Committee dockets. These dockets contain agenda books (later called "Treasurer's Reports") with portfolio reviews and summaries of investment holdings. The files also hold meeting minutes, reports and background memoranda, and proposed By-Laws amendments. Mr. Kennedy was responsible for preparing and distributing briefing materials about investment activities to Committee members for review in advance of meetings. The Tax Reform Act of 1969 also led the Foundation to amend its By-Laws to expand the powers and duties of the Vice President of Financial Affairs and the Treasurer and enable them to manage the Foundation's assets independently from the Board.

There are also memoranda discussing proposed new agreements between the Ford Motor Company and the Foundation regarding the sale and conversion of Ford Motor Company non-voting Class A stock. Other memoranda discuss the terms for continued use of external advisors to manage portions of the Foundation's investments.

Also part of Mr. Kennedy's Committee records are memoranda and correspondence pertaining to the Foundation's efforts to divest and diversify its portfolio of Ford Motor Company stock. There also is correspondence between Mr. Kennedy and then-President McGeorge Bundy regarding the Foundation's financial affairs.
Other files contain research memoranda and recommendations by investment research staff within the Office of the Treasurer.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Roger G. Kennedy was born in St. Paul, Minnesota in 1926. He received a B.A. from Yale University in 1949 and a law degree from the University of Minnesota. During the 1950s, he served as Special Assistant to the U.S. Attorney General; the U.S. Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare; and the U.S. Secretary of Labor. He began a career in banking during the 1960s, serving as Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Northwestern Bank of St. Paul, Minnesota and as Vice President of Investments at the University of Minnesota.

Mr. Kennedy joined the Ford Foundation in 1970 as Vice President of the Office of Finance. Charged with steering the Foundation towards achieving long-term sustainability despite the high inflation of the 1970s, he restructured expenditures and the investment portfolio. He also served as a key advisor on financial matters to President McGeorge Bundy and to the Board of Trustees' Finance Committee, and frequently prepared dockets and presented reports and recommendations to the Committee. The Finance Committee, initiated by the Board of Trustees in 1953, set investment policy and monitored the performance of the Foundation's portfolio. Finance Committee members during Mr. Kennedy's tenure included Stephen D. Bechtel, McGeorge Bundy, William H. Donaldson, John H. Loudon, J. Irwin Miller, Julius A. Stratton, and Bethuel M. Webster.

In 1978, Mr. Kennedy became Vice President of the newly created Office of the Arts (formerly Office of Humanities and the Arts). While in office, he drafted several reports assessing the field of grant-making in the arts and identified opportunities and possible focuses for grant-making. He also was involved with the Forty-Second Street Development Corporation and its efforts to revitalize the small theatre district of West 42nd Street.

Mr. Kennedy departed the Foundation in 1979 to become Director of the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History. From 1993 to 1997, he served as Director of the National Parks Service. He has also taught at Harvard, Yale and Stanford University.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation's Office of Finance, established in 1970, continued and expanded upon the functions of the Office of the Treasurer (1966-1970), the Office of the Treasury (1958-1966), and the Treasurer (prior to 1958). Its creation and mandate were shaped by the need for the Foundation to respond to two major financial developments. The first was passage of the Tax Reform Act of 1969, which increased federal scrutiny of the expenditure of all charities. The second was the threat that high rates of inflation and an unstable economy posed to the Foundation's assets and grant-making. The Office of Finance initiated stricter and more formalized procedures to guide the Foundation through this period of immense financial and economic change and uncertainty.

The Foundation's Board of Trustees' Finance Committee amended the By-Laws in 1970. The new amendments gave the Vice President of Finance and the Treasurer, acting jointly, sole power to buy and sell the Foundation's stock, bonds, and real estate assets. The Office of Finance retained an internal investment research staff to assist with the reshaping and diversification of the Foundation's investment portfolio.

The Office of the Arts originated as the Office of Humanities and the Arts, created in 1957 under the direction of its first Vice President, W. McNeil Lowry. In 1979, the Office of the Arts was restructured as a program area under Education and Public Policy and, after another reorganization in 1997, it became part of Education, Media, Arts and Culture. Education, Media, Arts and Culture was reorganized as the Knowledge, Creativity and Freedom Program in 2002.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.
Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details.

did.unittitle: Finance Committee Records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of agenda books, minutes, memoranda, Treasurer's Reports and briefing materials for quarterly Finance Committee meetings between 1970 and 1977. The briefing materials varied from meeting to meeting but held information about proposed amendments to the Foundation's By-Laws (1970), accountings of expenditures drawn from the General Reserve, and reviews of the Foundation's direct placement policy and portfolio. There are also memoranda regarding the sale and conversion of Ford Motor Company non-voting Class A stock and the terms for continued use of external advisors.

Office of the Arts Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of three files that describe activities of the Office of the Arts during Mr. Kennedy's tenure as Vice President. One file contains correspondence, memoranda and clippings about the Forty-Second Street Development Corporation and the role of the Foundation in the redevelopment of West 42nd Street and Theatre Row between 1978 and 1979. The other two files contain reports, "Why Bother about the Arts?" (March 1977), which reviews grant-making in the arts generally and makes a case for areas of focus, and "The Arts Office: A Two-Year Report," prepared by Mr. Kennedy for the November 1978 meeting of the Board of Trustees Arts Committee.

did.unittitle: Report -- "Why Bother About the Arts?"
Report -- "The Arts Office: A Two-Year Report"
Forty Second Street Local Development Corporation -- Memoranda and Clippings on Times Square Redevelopment
Speeches and Writings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of copies of Mr. Kennedy's speeches and writings on such topics as investment performance measurement; portfolio management, social responsibility, and philanthropy; and the effects of inflation.

Investment Research Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of the research the Office of Finance intended to shape Foundation investment decisions. The reports and recommendations are based on monitoring and analysis of the performance of companies and stocks. Lilia Clemente's files constitute the bulk of the series but research by other members of the investment staff Robert P. Bergin, Leo Bessera, Penney P. Burnett, Ruth S. Gamble, Curt W. Livingston, Ronn K. Lytle, Robert J. Powers, and Frank J. Prezelski is also included.
